facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 169-171 of 1955 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 169-171 of 1955. Appeals from the judgment and order dated July 10, 1953, of the Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 75, 87 and 135 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeals arise from the judgment and order dated July 10, 1953, of the Madras High Court dismissing Writ Petitions Nos. 75, 87 and 135 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated July 10, 1953, of the Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 75, 87 and 135 of 1953. Ganapathy Iyer and Shanmugavel, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions impugning the validity of the Madras Commercial Crops Markets Act XX of 1933, rules thereunder, and notifications issued by the first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: dismissing three writ petitions filed by the appellants impugning the validity of the provisions of the Madras Commercial Crops Markets Act  Mad XX of 1933 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, and the Rules framed thereunder, and certain numberifications issued by the first respondent herein in pursuance thereof.

facts.text: The Act was passed to provide for the better regulation of the buying and selling of commercial crops in the State of Madras and to establish markets.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed to provide for the better regulation of the buying and selling of companymercial crops in the State of Madras and for that purpose to establish markets and make Rules for their proper administration.

facts.text: On May 18, 1951, the State Government issued G.O. No. 1049 extending the provisions of the Act to Ramanathapuram and Tirunelveli Districts in respect of cotton and groundnuts.

anchor.surface_text: On May 18, 1951, the State Government issued G. 0. No. 1049  Food Agriculture Department  extending the provisions of the Act to Ramanathapuram and Tirunelveli Districts in respect of companyton and groundnuts.

facts.text: On February 25, 1952, the State Government issued G.O. No. 251 constituting Market Committees at Koilpatti and Sankarankoil in Tirunelveli District.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1952, the State Government issued G. 0. No. 251  Food Agriculture Department  ordering the companystitution of a Market Committee at Koilpatti and Sankarankoil in Tirunelveli District.

facts.text: By G.O. No. 356 dated March 8, 1952, the Government directed constitution of a Market Committee at Virudhunagar and markets at Virudhunagar, Rajapalayan and Sattur in Ramanathapuram District.

anchor.surface_text: By a similar G. O., viz., G. 0. No. 356  Food - Agriculture Department  dated March 8,1952, the Government directed the companystitution of a Market Committee at Virudhunagar and markets at  1  Virudhunagar  2  Rajapalayan and  3  Sattur in Ramanathapuram District.

facts.text: Market Committees were duly constituted.

anchor.surface_text: The Market Committees. were duly companystituted, and, on January 9, 1953, the Market Committee at Virudhunagar issued a numberice stating that the Act and the Rules had companye into force in Ramanathapuram District on January 1, 1953,

facts.text: On January 9, 1953, Virudhunagar Market Committee issued notice that Act and Rules came into force on January 1, 1953 in Ramanathapuram District, requiring licenses for cotton and groundnut business.

anchor.surface_text: on January 9, 1953, the Market Committee at Virudhunagar issued a numberice stating that the Act and the Rules had companye into force in Ramanathapuram District on January 1, 1953, and requiring persons who did business in companyton and groundnut to take out licences as provided therein.

facts.text: Virudhunagar notice dated January 17, 1953 stated traders failing to license by February 15, 1953 liable to prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: A further numberice dated January 17, 1953, stated that all the traders in companyton and groundnut, who failed to take out licences on or before February 15, 1953, were liable to prosecution.

facts.text: Tirunelveli Market Committee at Koilpatti issued notices dated January 22, 1953 and February 14, 1953 requiring licenses for cotton traders by February 28, 1953 or prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: Similar numberices dated January 22, 1953, and February 14, 1953, were issued by the Chairman, Tirunelveli Market Committee at Koilpatti calling upon all traders, producers and weighmen dealing in companyton to take out licences before February 28, 1953, and threatening prosecution for failure to companyply therewith.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions in Madras High Court against State of Madras, Collectors of concerned Districts, and Chairmen of Market Committees for writ of mandamus to forbear enforcing the Act, rules, bylaws.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in the above three appeals and others filed writ petitions in the High Court of Madras against  1  the State of Madras  2  the Collectors of the companycerned Districts and  3  the Chairmen of the Market Committees, for the issue of a Writ of Mandamus directing the respondents to forbear from enforcing any or all the provisions of the Act as amended and the Rules and Bylaws framed thereunder.

facts.text: Madras High Court Bench of Rajamanna C.J. and Venkatarama Aiyar J. dismissed writ applications on July 10, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: A Bench of the Madras High Court, companysisting of Rajamanna C. J. and Venkatarama Aiyar J. by an order dated July 10, 1953, dismissed the applications.

facts.text: High Court held s. 5(4)(a) of the Act void to the extent it conferred on Collector authority to refuse licence at discretion; rule 37 void insofar as prohibiting unregistered persons from business.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that s. 5 4  a  of the Act was void to the extent it companyferred on the Collector authority to refuse a licence at his own discretion and rule 37 was void in so far as it prohibited persons whose names had number yet been registered as buyers and sellers, from carrying on business in the numberified area.

facts.text: High Court upheld the Act and Rules under Art. 19(6) as valid marketing legislation, subject to above.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to that, the impugned Act and the Rules were upheld under Art. 19 6  of the Constitution as a valid piece of marketing legislation. In the result, the applications were dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals by certificate against High Court order dismissing applications.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid three appellants have filed these appeals against the order of the High Court in so far as it dismissed their applications.

facts.text: Appellants contend provisions of Act and Rules constitute unreasonable restriction on fundamental right to do business under Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellants companytends that the provisions of the Act and the Rules framed thereunder companystitute an unreasonable restriction upon the appellants fundamental right to do business

facts.text: The Act was passed on July 25, 1933.

anchor.surface_text: With a view to provide satisfactory companyditions for the growers of companymercial crops to sell their produce on equal terms and at reasonable prices, the Act was passed on July 25, 1933.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds impugned provisions constitute reasonable restrictions on right to do business and are valid.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that, having regard to the entire scheme of the Act, the impugned provisions of the Act companystitute reasonable restrictions on a citizens right to do business, and therefore, they are valid.

facts.text: Virudhunagar has a well-established market functioning for over fifty years.

anchor.surface_text: In Viradhunagar, there is already a well-established market which provides facilities for the purchase and sale of companyton and other goods. It is stated that the said market has been functioning for over fifty years,

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 19  1  g  of the Constitution of India all persons have the right to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business. Clause  6  of that Article enables the State to make any law imposing in the interest of general public reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right conferred by sub-cl.  g  of cl.  1 .

concepts.interpretation: Art.19(1)(g) confers fundamental right to carry on trade or business; Art.19(6) allows reasonable restrictions in interest of general public.

concepts.interpretation: Licensing requirement for purchase/sale/storage etc. of commercial crops in notified areas constitutes reasonable restriction under Art.19(6).

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that, having regard to the entire scheme of the Act, the impugned provisions of the Act constitute reasonable restrictions on a citizens right to do business, and therefore, they are valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analyzed legislative object to protect growers from middlemen exploitation via regulated markets and licensing; applied reasonableness test from precedents (rational nexus, no excess); rejected petitioner arguments on fees, grower/trader burdens, radius as lacking evidence or misconstruing scheme.

precedents.case_name: Chintaman Rao v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: in order to be reasonable, a restriction must have a rational relation to the object which the legislature seeks to achieve and must not go in excess of that object

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. V. G. ROW  2

anchor.surface_text: State of Madras v. V. G. ROW  2  thus It is important in this context to bear in mind that the test of reasonableness, wherever prescribed, should be applied to each individual statute impugned, and no abstract standard, or general pattern, of reasonableness can be laid down as applicable to all cases. The nature of the right alleged to have been infringed, the underlying purpose of the restrictions imposed, the extent and urgency of the evil sought to be remedied thereby, the disproportion of the imposition, the prevailing conditions at the time, should all enter into the judicial verdict.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. V. G. Row
precedents.cited_proposition: the test of reasonableness, wherever prescribed, should be applied to each individual statute impugned, and no abstract standard, or general pattern, of reasonableness can be laid down as applicable to all cases. The nature of the right alleged to have been infringed, the underlying purpose of the restrictions imposed, the extent and urgency of the evil sought to be remedied thereby, the disproportion of the imposition, the prevailing conditions at the time, should all enter into the judicial verdict.
